alert.note: Alert for Apache; Navajo (Arizona) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued August 24 at 1:13PM MST until August 24 at 4:15PM MST by NWS Flagstaff
info.description: The National Weather Service in Flagstaff has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... Navajo County in north central Arizona... Apache County in northeastern Arizona... * Until 415 PM MST. * At 112 PM MST, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain across the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. HAZARD...Life-threatening flash flooding. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life-threatening flash flooding of normally dry washes and roads. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Chinle, Tselani-Cottonwood, Burnside, Salina, Nazlini, Hubbell Trading Post National Historic Site, Kinlichee Chapter House, Blue Gap Chapter House, Whippoorwill Chapter House, Low Mountain, Ganado, Navajo Reservation and Hopi Reservation. This includes the following highways... State Route 264 between mile markers 429 and 465. Highway 191 between mile markers 403 and 446. This includes the following washes... Meadow Wash, Ruin Wash, Burnt Corn Wash, Burnt Piqon Wash, Keams Canyon Wash, Wepo Wash, Wide Ruin Wash, Beshbito Wash, Steamboat Wash, Sage House Wash, Kinlichee Creek, Pueblo Colorado Wash, Fish Wash, Balakai Wash, Scattered Willow Wash, Tiis Ndiitsooi Wash, Hipbone Wash, Lone Tule Wash, Polacca Wash, Bis Ii Ah Wash, Cottonwood Wash, Piney Hill Creek, Sitting Giant Rock Wash, Chinle Wash, Red Clay Wash, Black Mountain Wash, Tah Chee Wash, Bitter Water Wash, Cold Spring Wash, Oraibi Wash, Jeddito Wash, Black Soil Wash, Tse Chizzi Wash, Tse Deeshzhaai Wash, Coyote Wash, Nazlini Wash and Tse Ba Ni Zi Ni Wash. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Remain alert for flooding even in locations not receiving rain. Normally dry washes can become raging killer currents in a matter of minutes, even from distant rainfall.
